question: Q. What are the general literary divisions of the Old Testament?
answer: A. Pentateuch, Historical Books, Wisdom Literature, Prophets.

question: Q. What are the general literary divisions of the New Testament?
answer: A. Gospels and Acts, Pauline Epistles, General Epistles, and Revelation.

question: Walk through the Romans Road (share the gospel).
answer:
Our Condition and Its Severity
  • Rom. 3:23 – for all have sinned and fall short of the glory of God,
  • Rom. 6:23 – For the wages of sin is death…
    Our Hope
  • Rom. 6:23 – but the gift of God is eternal life in Christ Jesus our Lord.
  • Rom. 5:8 – but God shows his love for us in that while we were still sinners, Christ died for us
    Our Response
  • Rom. 10:9 – because, if you confess with your mouth that Jesus is Lord and believe in your heart that God raised him from the dead, you will be saved.
    Our Assurance
  • Rom. 5:1 – Therefore, since we have been justified by faith, we have peace with God through our Lord Jesus Christ.
  • Rom. 8:1 – There is therefore now no condemnation for those who are in Christ Jesus.

question: Q. How would you address tithing from Scripture?
answer: A. Deut. 14 and Lev. 27 speak to the requirement in the Old Testament to set aside 10% of our firstfruits and return them to God in thanksgiving. We are encouraged in continued giving (Acts 15) and giving alms (Acts 6). In light of our future inheritance (1 Peter 1), we are freed from feeling tied and bound to worldly riches, and can act as the Gentile church in their offering (2 Cor. 8-9)

question: References for covenants under the Covenant of Grace
answer:
Proto-euangelion – Promised seed (Gen. 3:15)
Noahic – Promise to never again destroy by flood (Gen. 9)
Abrahamic – Father of a great nation (Gen. 12, 15, 17)
Mosaic – Law at Mount Sinai, establishing a covenant with Israel and providing guidelines for living in harmony with God (Ex. 19-24; Deut. 28)
Davidic – Promise of permenant dynasty (2 Sam. 7)
.New Covenant – God promises to write his laws on the hearts of his people and to forgive their sins through the blood of Jesus Christ.(Jeremiah 31; Ezekiel 36)
